results.title: O Brother where art thou ? [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures, Touchstone Pictures, Studio Canal, Working Title Films, Ethan Coen and Joel Coen
results.brief_description: Another Cohen production, “O Brother where art thou?” follows the black comedy tradition of “The Big Lebowski” and “Fargo”. Once again the story centre arounds hapless anti-heroes who stumble from one humorous disaster to another. The story is set in America’s South during the time of the depression. It loosely follows Homer’s Odyssey, but instead of soldiers, the heroes are criminals on the run, escapees from a chain gang eager to retrieve cash from a robbery. The trio are lead by George Clooney’s character Everett Ulysess McGill, a likeable rogue who has a passion for bryl creem. Like Odysseus, Everett and his fellow escapees eventually reach their destination only to find not all is as it was or as they were lead to believe.

results.title: Nylon goes to work
results.creator_credit: Film Producers Guild, British Nylon Spinners, Harold Goodwin and R.Q. McNaughton
results.brief_description: Nylon is used for some of the toughest jobs in British industry. This film takes twelve examples to illustrate some of the material’s unique characteristics, ranging from nylon rope, such as that used to haul Thames barges, to the use of the material in fire hoses and the tyres of aircraft.

results.title: Nuts to you
results.brief_description: Two Neanderthals, in order not to be exploited by “fast operators” learned to share the leftovers equally with each other, that adding two odd numbers gives an even number, that in adding even numbers the sum will always be an even number and finally, if a number can be divided by two it is an even number. No other credits available.

results.title: Nutritional needs of our bodies
results.brief_description: Using photomicrography, laboratory animals, and animation, shows how food provides the body’s basic needs. Describes the four general groups of foods, the nutrients which they contain, and what the nutrients supply to the body. The importance of a well-balanced diet to a strong body and good health is stressed.

results.title: Nutrition: the consumer and the supermarket
results.creator_credit: Barr Films and William C. Crain
results.brief_description: The supermarket offers convenience and a ready source of the food we need. But there are thousands of products on the supermarket shelves - how do we determine what to buy? Here consumer interviews are combined with an analysis of the products and merchandising techniques used in the market. Basic information is presented to assist the shopper.

results.title: Nutrition: the all-American meal
results.creator_credit: Barr Films and William C. Crain
results.brief_description: Analyses the nutritional and sociological implications of the “hamburger, chips and soft drink American diet.” Offers suggestions for improving the nutritional value of meals.

results.title: Nutrition: fueling the human machine
results.creator_credit: Columbia Broadcasting System and BFA Educational Media
results.brief_description: Enumerates the facts of nutrition that affect our physical health and well-being. Encourages a balanced and varied diet, discusses the possible dangers of food additives and sugar, and emphasises the importance of exercise to avoid obesity. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Nutrition for sports: facts and fallacies
results.creator_credit: Alfred Higgins Productions and Stephen Wallen
results.brief_description: Looks at the dietary needs of people involved in physical activity. Discusses the basic components of a balanced diet and clearly shows the misconceptions that the general public has of the athlete’s nutritional requirements.

results.title: Nutrition and the pig
results.creator_credit: Birch Hill Film Productions, Unilever Films, Dudley Birch and Bertram Tyrer
results.brief_description: Shows research into the nutrition of the pig, whose digestive system strongly resembles that of humans. Explains how various problems are all related to specific nutritional deficiencies.
